awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity in Linguistics, STEM and Technology through the Documentation of the North Slope Dialect of Inupiaq, an endangered Native Alaskan language
awd_abstract_narration:
The essential elements that constitute the minimal scientific documentation of a language include a reference grammar, a dictionary, and transcribed narratives with translations and linguistic analysis. In contemporary language documentation projects, an especially important role is often played by electronic databases, which structure a set of data and allow multiple routes to search for information. With the advent of digital tools, databases often incorporate richer data and documentation, including sound files, photographs, grammatical information, and entire stories. This project will document document the North Slope Dialect of Iñupiaq, a highly endangered Native Alaskan language, and it will create and expand a database of the language. This language documentation will add to the current knowledge of Native languages while building scientific research capacities at Alaska's only tribal college. The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages, including Alaska Native languages. Broader impacts include introducing Iḷisaġvik College students to linguistic research, creating institutional partnerships with the University of Alaska Fairbanks -- home to the Alaska Native Language Archive -- and providing source materials for Iñupiaq faculty in the instruction of Iñupiaq language, and in the fields of science, technology and the humanities. In addition, increased interaction with technology by tribal college students and community youth will increase participants' skills in the technological field,  creating a stronger STEM workforce in Alaska. 

The creation and expansion of the North Alaskan Iñupiaq Database will document this important Native language and will be a tool to introduce tribal college students to applications of technology design and linguistics. Bringing together elder speakers and the community's tech savvy youth, this project centers around an innovative, reciprocal exchange of knowledge, the elders' expertise in the indigenous language versus youth knowledge of technology.  Ways of knowing and understanding will be documented in the language.  The team, coordinated by Erin Hollingsworth of Iḷisaġvik College's Tuzzy Consortium Library, will produce endangered language research, engage in community outreach with members in remote Alaskan sites, and create participating opportunities for tribal college students. The project will also create high quality science resources for educators, while further strengthening the scientific capacity at Iḷisaġvik College.  The North Slope Iñupiaq language material will be accessible to linguists, tribal community members, and the general public through the database. Databases for endangered and other languages advance knowledge by increasing access to linguistic, historical, cultural and scientific materials, especially when disseminated in online formats. The NSF Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUP) program in EHR is providing support for tribal college participation in this project.

por.por_cntn:
It was the goal of this project to create a website for the Iñupiaq community of the North Slope that both collected cultural information and provided online access to information about the North Slope-based Iñupiaq language, culture, and history. We aimed to find and produce content that could be used to encourage interest the Iñupiaq language by future generations.

Although we have tried to highlight topics of interest to scholars whenever possible, the intended audience for this project was always the Iñupiaq community of the North Slope. The project team chose early on to focus on the production of video recordings for public consumption, partly because these are of greater interest to the audience we intended to reach.

The team combed through a variety of video and audio recordings collected by Iḷisaġvik College over the years in search of relevant materials. Although the college, had recorded several events and classes over the years, it lacked the staff to develop the recordings into material useful for public consumption. Identifying useful recordings and translating them into an accessible form became one of the first tasks of the project team. We found classroom lessons on language, culture, and history as well less formal occasions wherein members of the Iñupiaq community commented on these same topics. In each case, we edited the source material so as to produce user-friendly video content for interested community members.

The team also conducted a number of interviews with stakeholders in the Iñupiaq community of the North Slope. Interview subjects talked about a range of topics from their personal lives to politics at the local, state, national, and international level. They addressed questions about their language, specific cultural practices, climate change, and a number of related themes in the local history of the North Slope. Two prominent themes emerging from this material include the personal experiences of Iñupiat in both local day-schools and distant boarding schools as well as the history of research on local wildlife (particularly whales) on the North Slope. The former is of obvious interest to historical linguistics insofar as it sheds light on the language ideologies influencing different generations of North Slope Iñupiat. The later is a testament to the value of traditional ecological knowledge in the scientific community. This knowledge is embedded in linguistic practices of Iñupiaq speakers. It is also reflected in statements our subjects made about the effects of climate change. We encountered a broad range of additional topics of interest, but these are two of the strongest themes emerging from the interviews.

The project team gathered more materials than we could process by the close of the grant, so the long-term project continues. We have loaded all completed video content onto a web-page, entitled Quiliaqtuat, and sorted them according to major categories such as politics, language, history, etc.  Additional material will be uploaded to the website as it becomes available for the indefinite future. A detailed table of contents will be added to the website in the summer of 2023. As it stands, the collection of materials on Quiliagtuat will provide a valuable asset to Iḷisaġvik College and to the Iñupiaq community of the North Slope.
